title: Are there any terms and conditions between an author and a publisher? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: Heaven’s yes! It’s called a contract. It spells out, among other things, who owns the copyright, when the book (or books) are due, when the edits and rewrites are due, how long the mss is expected to be, how much the advance( if any) will be, what the royalties will be after the book earns out and how often they will be paid, what editions this covers (e.g. hardback, mass market, paperback, ebook) and what rights for screenplays. foreign sales are covered. Most agents will also want a signed contract before they begin trying to sell your book to a publisher.

Yes, it all depends on what mode you chose to publish your book among “Traditional publishing” and “Self-publishing”. Usually, in traditional publications, publishers come up with more terms and conditions. In self-publication, an author is free to choose any publisher who fulfills his requirement. I hope this information helps!
Obviously, no publisher will work without any terms of agreement
